body: btw im cloning master, maybe i need to clone some branch?
Thanks!

I am using master. Windows 10 with Python 3.4 x86_64.

Is it possible for you to try Python 3.4? I cannot install mxnet with
python 2.7 on my machine. It requires vcpython27, which only supports
windows 7/8/8.1.   @_@

@tqchen Could you please confirm this naming? Then I can finish it asap.
i replied to that earlier - im using 32 bit python. So there is no way to install on 32 bit python under windows?
Or stacked RBMs. Okay, thanks for answer!
Fixed in PR #737

@pluskid 
I try to train a multi-label net.  I use the im2rec tool to create a 2-label dataset. As you said, I define the symbols as follows

```
input_data = mx.symbol.Variable(name="data")
. . . shared ConvLayer  . . .
softmax1 = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data=fc3, name='softmax1')
softmax2 = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data=fc3, name='softmax2')
softmax = mx.symbol.Group([softmax1, softmax2])
```

then I run the code and an error occured:

```
Symbol.InterShapeKeyword argument name softmax_label not found.
```

I have no idea how to fix it . 
and how cound I know whether softmax1 corresponds to label_1 and softmax2  corresponds to label_2
This is great, please fix the lint error and it can be merged https://travis-ci.org/dmlc/mxnet/jobs/93536389
@antinucleon can you review and merge this one?
@tqchen  I suggest tot delete this notebook, and only keep: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/image-classification
how about review and merge this, and move it to https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/image-classification

@winstywang @tqchen Hmmm as someone who isn't an extremely fluent C/C++ programmer, I don't know how to proceed. My use case is quite simple, I'd like to:
- Load a model file that was already trained in Python
- Load image file(s)
- Output a prediction(s)

in C++. If putting together an example like this is so difficult, then Tensorflow seems a much better choice. (Not in any way on a knock on this project or maintainers. Rather a question of usecase and dev time.)

My view of this library was it was meant to be for this sort of thing, but it seems more research oriented.
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/neural-style
so cool, how is the speed? let me write a blog for advertising it.

You need to also seed numpy and random to guarantee reproducibility.
@tqchen should we also seed those in mx.random.seed by default?
Could you be more specific? How are you using this code? What's the error?

Hi nowozin, Thanks for the contribution. I made a few comments. Otherwise looks good to me.

As to the confusion about grad functions. I think it's a fair point. @tqchen @antinucleon  what do you think.
not well done yet. @antinucleon is still on training a smaller model to make it fast
I was able to fix the linting error by using the throwaway variable name `_` for the memo dict. Rebased on master and squashed the two commits.

I met the same issue as reported by @zmactep. I changed "USE_BLAS = openblas" and then got the following new error

```
 ld: library not found for -lopenblas
 clang: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation)
```

Just FYI: w/o using GPU, I can compile mxnet successfully on Mac OS X 10.11.
@leocnj you need to install openblas first

@piiswrong I already installed openblas through brew. This is also why I can compile mxnet (only on the CPU running condition) successfully. 

Now, I truly need the function of using GPUs to work. Just found a [StackOverflow Q/A][http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11632919/cuda-programming-and-xcode] talking about a similar issue. It looks that clang and CUDA may have a communication issue. Hope this link will allow other folks with more experiences on OS X programming to come up a solution.

So the logic is if you have multiple loss, like "softmax1", and "softmax2", then you will need to provide labels for them in your data iterator, like "softmax1_label" and "softmax2_label". Otherwise, it does not know how to evaluate the losses.
I tried the example, and got `Please compile with CUDA enabled`.  Is it silly to try to run this example without cuda?  I don't need a ton of speed and want to try it on a device without a gpu.
Seems test failed?

use --gpu -1 to disable gpu
On Sat, Nov 28, 2015 at 10:39 AM Zach Mayer notifications@github.com
wrote:

> I tried the example, and got Please compile with CUDA enabled. Is it
> silly to try to run this example without cuda? I don't need a ton of speed
> and want to try it on a device without a gpu.
>

@winstywang @piiswrong
I will take a look today. Sorry for the delay.
Just an estimation that the Lua version took about 40-60 minutes on CPU and 2 min on GPU, so we may expect 20-30 min on CPU with mxnet

Looks good to me.
BTW, I also need multi input upsampling (basically upsampling + concat) that takes n_c_1_w_1_h_1 ... n_c_k_w_k_h_k and output n_(c_1+...+c_k)_w*h. This is useful for multi resolution feature (i.e. hypercolumn) and saves one memory allocation.
I'll refactor this if no one beats me to it.
I am out side and I will probably add bilinear upsampling in upsampling symbol. For multi input upsampling, can we use two symbol to do that? I
Using to symbols will result in doubling the memory used.
K, I only use this for GAN and double memoir doesn't hurt me seems. Also for bilinear seems we need to do similar thing.  I will use symbol first to make GAN work.
Fair point. I think the current solution is fine.

@pluskid What is the semantics of using multiple loss functions in a `Group` within the context of `FeedForward`?

I would guess that the sum of all elements in the `Group` is being minimized.  If this is the case, maybe the documentation of `FeedForward` and multiple losses should clearly state this.

@nowozin Yes, one could think of it a a sum. Or alternatively, one could think that each loss function is back-propagating gradients (independently) and the gradients get merged for each parameter. The LSTM example (in Julia) use grouped multi-loss in `FeedForward` for example.

I'm not sure how and where should we document this. Because it seems very natural to me (maybe because I already know the implementation details). Do you have any suggestions?

seems good to me.
@piiswrong For hypercolumn, it is better to implement bilinear upsamping or use the deconv directly.
Could you run `pkg-config --libs opencv` and post your output?

We could also implement bilinear upsampling with the deconvolution layer, but we would need a way to prevent changes to the weights. See https://github.com/dmlc/MXNet.jl/pull/34 for a first implementation on the Julia side.
I have tried to compile without CUDA, and it success.
Thx piiswrong, to also seed numpy solved it.

The problem is the version of g++ or gcc I am working with.
It is very similar with caffe's problem you may referred to https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/caffe-users/a6TDx89IByY/49ZD6rtyCwAJ

```

Description-en: development files for opencv
 This is a metapackage providing development package necessary for
 development of OpenCV (Open Computer Vision).
 .
 The Open Computer Vision Library is a collection of algorithms and sample
 code for various computer vision problems. The library is compatible with
 IPL (Intel's Image Processing Library) and, if available, can use IPP
 (Intel's Integrated Performance Primitives) for better performance.
 .
 OpenCV provides low level portable data types and operators, and a set
 of high level functionalities for video acquisition, image processing and
 analysis, structural analysis, motion analysis and object tracking, object
 recognition, camera calibration and 3D reconstruction.
```

Hi @korneil, thanks for the post. I was wondering if you manage to get it running?
what do you mean dont need concat? does this handle multiple input without duplicating memory?
I don't really know what happened, but maybe you can try adding the output of `pkg-config --libs opencv` to LDFLAGS in config.mk

After init the bilinear weight with

```
weight = np.zeros(np.prod(shape))
f = shape[3] / 2.
c = (2 * f - 1 - f % 2) / (2. * f)
for i in range(np.prod(shape)):
    x = i % shape[3]
    y = (i / shape[3]) % shape[2]
    weight[i] = (1 - abs(x / f - c)) * (1 - abs(y / f - c));
```

the result is:

original image:
![original](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1258974/11460786/eb7ba916-96b0-11e5-8d5d-096b83a8d6b0.jpg)

nearest result:
![nearest](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1258974/11460788/f56ebe22-96b0-11e5-8058-821964cc3690.jpg)

bilinear result:
![bilinear](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1258974/11460790/fd3ec9f8-96b0-11e5-891f-2c8e6a65c4cc.jpg)

Hi Kayhan,

Thanks for using MXNet. @korneil  is working on this, and a WIP PR can be found at:
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/697

After it is finished, we will support 3D conv

@piiswrong I have finished bilinear upsampling. For hypercolumn or concat, I am not very clear about these and feel free to refactor for your purpose. 

BTW. Travis lint system is not working correctly.
I think it's easy to do for nearest neighbor. I'll do it after you merge this.
What happened to travis lint? Did the rule set change?
https://travis-ci.org/dmlc/mxnet/jobs/93842415 ,seems are errors with numpy and some more strict rules.

The pre-built binary distribution is 64bit. So you will need 64bit python
to use that package. I think it is also possible to built 32bit mxnet and
use it in 32bit python. Let me have a try.

``` c++

        input_shape = (5,3,100,100),
        num_filter = 3,

```

I train model on 7 and 15 GPU machines which equipped with four K40m gpu card
@zhubuntu you probably want to take a look at this: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/750
You'll need a custom metric for that, check python/mxnet/metric.py
Probably should add a makefile?

first example, which uses the NDArray interface directly to perform a
simple c = a + b. Stay tuned for more examples.

@piiswrong right. Let me add a makefile. Travis checking is complaining about some format errors in Python files, which I didn't touch at all. Do you know what is going on?
It's happening to all PR. somehow the rules for python got more strict. No idea where this came from

I'm now making a C++ program which reads a pre-trained model and classify a jpg file. Here is the current program (still incomplete): https://github.com/caprice-j/mxnet/blob/master/example/image-classification-cplusplus/predict.cc

I succeeded as to calling MXPredCreate() with no compile error, but when I executed the C++ program it showed: 

$ ./predict
[16:19:22] ./dmlc-core/include/dmlc/./logging.h:208: [16:19:22] src/operator/operator.cc:19: Cannot find Operator FullyConnected in registry

From this log message, it seemed like I have to register "FullyConnected" symbol, but when I add 

MXNET_REGISTER_OP_PROPERTY(FullyConnected, mxnet::op::FullyConnectedProp);

in my predict.cc: line 19, then another error message showed and segfaulted:

[16:19:03] ../../dmlc-core/include/dmlc/./logging.h:208: [16:19:03] ../../dmlc-core/include/dmlc/registry.h:53: Check failed: (fmap_.count(name)) == (0) FullyConnected already registered
libc++abi.dylib: terminating with uncaught exception of type dmlc::Error: [16:19:03] ../../dmlc-core/include/dmlc/registry.h:53: Check failed: (fmap_.count(name)) == (0) FullyConnected already registered
Abort trap: 6

I'd like to ask you of how to deal with this problem.
I'm using "model/mnist-0-symbol.json" and "model/mnist-0-0001.params" as a test pre-trained model (borrowed from the example/image-classification directory).

another 2 tips puzzled me in conv and deconv:
1. i think [convolution-inl.h#L243](https://github.com/tornadomeet/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/convolution-inl.h#L243) should be changed to `index_t nstep = std::max(std::min(static_cast<index_t>(workspace_size / (shape_colunit_.Size()+shape_dstunit_ .Size())),ishape[0]), 1U);` because the workspace is used for both "indata" and "outdata",and we should consider the "outdata".
2. why it must add `if (nstep_ == nstep) {nstep_ = std::max(nstep_ - 1, 1U); }`, i.e. minus one from nsteps_?

yes

OK. Can you try to add `ctx=mx.cpu()` in `mx.mlp`, just like

```
mx.mlp(data.matrix(x[nonval.ind,]), y[nonval.ind], ctx=mx.cpu(),
                  hidden_node=c(400,100), 
                  out_node=2, out_activation=softmax,
                  num.round=12, array.batch.size=50, 
                  learning.rate=0.01, momentum=0.5, 
                  dropout = 0.5, activation = tanh,
                  eval.data = val.dat, eval.metric=mx.metric.accuracy)
```

I have tried it, but the problem remains there.
